docs.snippet: Sure, third-party Facebook apps collected data about users’ lives. But they seemed convenient and harmless, and, really, what could go wrong?

headline.print_headline: How Did Data Sharing Go From Feature to Bug On Facebook?
headline.main: How Facebook’s Data Sharing Went From Feature to Bug

docs.snippet: Getting rid of your Facebook account will only offload the platform’s problems onto someone else.

headline.main: Don’t Delete Facebook. Do Something About It.

docs.snippet: If you no longer wish to use Facebook’s message-sharing app on your smartphone, you can uninstall it.
Was it the reason Trump won? That’s the wrong question.
Readers suggest ways of preventing the next occurrence.
After learning how advisers to Donald Trump exploited the company’s vulnerabilities to get him elected, Congress needs to strengthen privacy laws.

headline.main: Facebook Leaves Its Users’ Privacy Vulnerable

docs.snippet: Mark Zuckerberg held a Wednesday meeting with staff, followed by a regularly scheduled meeting on Friday, partly to discuss the Cambridge Analytica scandal.

headline.print_headline: With Morale Drooping, Zuckerberg Speaks With Facebook Employees
headline.main: Zuckerberg Takes Steps to Calm Facebook Employees

docs.snippet: In the wake of the Cambridge Analytica scandal, in which data from over 50 million Facebook profiles was secretly scraped and mined for voter insights, many Facebook users have decided to delete their accounts — but untangling yourself from a site...

headline.main: Why Leaving Facebook Doesn’t Always Mean Quitting

docs.snippet: The Federal Trade Commission confirmed an inquiry as a group of attorneys general asked Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, for more information.

headline.main: Demands Grow for Facebook to Explain Its Privacy Policies

docs.snippet: Shares of technology companies plunged as investors fretted that tougher government oversight could hurt the sector’s profits.

headline.main: Facebook and Other Tech Companies Drag Down Stock Markets
